author: Aysia Reed, WGME
title: chevron-right
text: HARPSWELL (WGME) - Several storms left Maine coastal communities devastated over the last few months, which hit the fishing industry especially hard. Dilapidated wharfs, massive piles of plywood, debris scattered everywhere: this is just some of the aftermath of the storm’s impact on Harpswell last weekend. CEO of New England Fisherman Stewardship Association, Jerry Leeman, says these past couple storms have damaged some of the infrastructure that Maine’s fishermen rely on. "Fixing these structures up especially here locally is going to be a pivotal point for keeping sustainable product on the American dinner table,” said Leeman. Senator Susan Collins met with a dozen fishermen in Harpswell Saturday to see the aftermath from those storms and the impact it is having on Maine fishermen. She says structures on Bailey Island here, that cost the town $10,000, were destroyed between both storms in January. "I want to do everything that I can to try to secure assistance working with the governor, the local community, with the rest of the delegation,” said Collins. Leeman says 85% of this town is commercial fishing wharfs, these structures are vital to fisherman for their livelihoods. Some might appear to be in good enough shape, but fishermen say they need serious repairs. "Just look at the wharf behind us here,” said Leeman. “Even though it's structurally still standing, if you go under it, that entire wharf has to come down." Collins emphasized how much this community and industry means to the state and its economy. "It helps to attract millions of tourists; it helps to define our way of life. It's part of our heritage,” said Collins. Leeman is a fifth-generation fisherman and says it's painful to see this destruction. "When you see things that were there when you were a child, and they're no longer there, it takes a piece of you,” said Leeman. Leeman says this is just the beginning and hopes this town can receive federal dollars to build back. This community is willing to do anything they can to help out their local fishermen. "We don't stop. You just pick yourself up, dust yourself off and keep going,” said Leeman.

author: Quanecia Fraser
title: 'I don't want to forget where I came from': Fremont Police's unique mental health co-responder program
text:
'I don't want to forget where I came from': Fremont Police's unique co-responder program
The Fremont Police Department says a unique resource is helping people feel more at ease when it comes mental health crises. Since late 2023, the department has been using a co-responder to help officers on mental health-related calls.
Fremont Police says most departments with a program like this used a licensed therapist. But they use a peer support specialist instead. That's someone who is trained under a licensed therapist to provide mental health support.
Whenever he's on the clock, you can find Jon Thomsen at the Fremont Police Station. But he's no police officer.
"My role here is to respond with officers, to mental health, behavioral health crises," Thomsen said.
He's a co-responder working for Lutheran Family Services.
"Our goal is to help people, get de-escalated, get stabilized and be able to stay in their homes, stay with their families and in the community," he told KETV.
Thomsen follows up with people too, even if the situation happened while he wasn't at work.
"Sometimes, they need to be in the hospital, I needed to be in the hospital," he said.
2012 was when Thomsen first stepped foot in a psychiatric unit.
"My story really starts when I was growing up," he said. "I learned that mental health issues aren't something that are safe to talk about."
He says that led to a long, difficult battle.
"I started using in junior high. And that went forward through high school," Thomsen said." I identify as an addict because I do not want to forget where I came from."
After getting help as an adult, his therapist suggested he become a peer support specialist.
"That lived experience is something that you can't teach and not everybody has that," said Brad Negrete, assistant vice president of health and wellness services for Lutheran Family Services.
"We are able to have somebody here who has firsthand knowledge and understanding of what people are going through," said Fremont Police Deputy Chief Jennifer Birkhofer.
For Thomsen, it's not just a job but a purpose he doesn't take lightly.
"Now, I get to use that darkness as a light to walk into other people's darkness and walk with them while they find their way out," Thomsen said.
The program at the Fremont Police Department is funded by Region 6 behavioral healthcare. But starting in July, it will be funded by the Fremont Family Coalition and Nebraska Crime Commission.

author: RecentlyHeard
title: Eva Mendes Suits Up for Her 'Jimmy Fallon' Appearance, Talks New Book
text: If you buy an independently reviewed services or products via a hyperlink on our web site, WWD could obtain an affiliate fee. Eva Mendes suited up for her current look on “The Tonight Present Starring Jimmy Fallon” on Wednesday. “The Place Past the Pines” star chatted with the eponymous discuss present host about her new youngsters’s e-book, “Desi, Mami and the By no means-Ending Worries.” For her late-night discuss present look, Mendes opted for a suited look. The youngsters’s e-book writer wore a checkered go well with with autumnal tones in shades of brown and taupe, amongst different hues. The look featured wide-leg, high-waisted trousers with a coordinated sample to the blazer. Mendes’ blazer featured cuffs rolled to her elbows. The only-breasted blazer additionally included pockets and sharp lapels. Beneath her blazer, Mendes opted for a easy white high with a scoop neckline. She accomplished the ensemble with pointed toe heels that includes a snakeskin print and translucent parts. As for her equipment, Mendes continued to favor autumnal tones, pairing her look with gold jewellery items. The “Hitch” star wore two assertion rings, bracelets and a pair of daring earrings to intensify her sartorial assertion. Mendes’ look was curated by stylist Cher Coulter, who’s additionally labored with “Downton Abbey” star Michelle Dockery, amongst others. Throughout her time on the discuss present, Mendes spoke about her new youngsters’s e-book, “Desi, Mami and the By no means-Ending Worries,” revealing how she hopes the e-book will affect each youngsters and fogeys. Mendes hopes the e-book is “inspiring, hopefully, dad and mom to attach via studying as a result of I really like that connection,” she mentioned. “It’s about actually not believing every little thing you suppose,” Mendes mentioned of her debut youngsters’s e-book. Together with writing “Desi, Mami, and the By no means-Ending Worries,” Mendes has been busy with a brand new partnership with Stella McCartney. Mendes fronts the London-based designer’s fall 2024 marketing campaign. The style label makes use of the autumn 2024 marketing campaign as a strategy to reinforce the “It’s About F-king Time” environmental manifesto. The marketing campaign, which additionally options singer Raye, spotlight’s the model’s initiatives and advocacy for sustainability and cruelty-free practices within the vogue trade. Photographs for the marketing campaign have been captured by photographer Ethan James Inexperienced. ‘Desi, Mami, and the By no means Ending Worries’
